title: FinMango Awarded $50,000 Grant from Google Health to Continue Collaboration on the COVID-19 Open Data Project.
excerpt: FinMango, a data-driven non-profit that promotes financial literacy, education, and advocacy around the world, has been awarded a $50,000 grant from Google Health to continue collaboration on Google’s COVID-19 Open Data Project.
body:
FinMango, a data-driven non-profit that promotes financial literacy, education, and advocacy around the world, has been awarded a $50,000 grant from Google Health to continue collaboration on Google’s COVID-19 Open Data Project.

The COVID-19 Open Data Project is the world's most comprehensive COVID-19 dataset; we track sub-national cases and vaccine deployment data for 20,000+ distinct locations in over 190 countries. Our data has influenced vaccine research, government public policy decisions, and travel safety measures, amongst other things. Additionally, our data has been used by numerous international organizations, including The WHO (Covax), The World Bank, IMF, Harvard University Research, USAID, and Verily, to name a few.

Since the inception of the project, the goals of the collaboration have remained the same:

  1. Help decision-makers understand the unique impact of COVID-19 on different communities,
  2. Provide timely, transparent, and unbiased data about the pandemic, and
  3. Establish partnerships with data providers and users to collect facts and extract insights.

Over the years, we have learned a thing or two about uniting people from different communities, backgrounds, and countries to make a positive impact on the world together. FinMango will use this grant to thank our volunteers, who have dedicated countless hours from their personal lives, education, and careers, to plug the data gap and attempt to create information symmetry between organizations during this devastating pandemic.

For more about the project and what we’re up to, visit covid.finmango.org.

Current contributors [with length of time on the project] include: Pam Hoalt, PhD [14 months], James Glasgow PhD [14 months], James Glasgow Pharm.D. [14 months], Rebeca Lozano [14 months], Kishan Patel [14 months], Uday Patel [14 months], Enrico Buoro [14 months], Scott Glasgow [14 months], Ojasvinee Singh [12 months], Kevin D'Souza [12 months], Martin Noguera [12 months], and Nathan Immel [1 month].

title: How the Pandemic Inspires Me to Build Resilience Around the World
excerpt: By Scott Glasgow There’s something that happens when adversity strikes that changes the way you look at life.
body:
By Scott Glasgow

There’s something that happens when adversity strikes that changes the way you look at life. This year, I was lucky enough to overcome that adversity with resilience—the ability to absorb, adapt, and transform.

It’s crazy to think about how different things were just a few months ago. I was working 80+ hours a week, jumping on flights to speak around the world, and not understanding the concept of work-life balance. FinMango had little focus and I was struggling to keep it all together.

But today, I got to look back on a year of wins, losses and learning and take comfort in the fact that we didn’t ever run out of money, and we did manage to mostly keep it all together. And thanks to a few lucky breaks—like smashing a world record, launching a collaboration with Google, and gaining national media coverage—we’re now focused and jumping into an incredible future.

With the year quickly coming to a close, I’m motivated to work harder than ever to solve the financial exclusion problem. FinMango can now be defined by three words: Data, Tech, and Advocacy. You can read more about the pivot here.

While I’m grateful for how radically different my life has changed during the pandemic compared to the average person, recognizing this is a reminder of how important it is to use the privilege and opportunities we are given to help those around us.

At FinMango, all we do is give. We give people the opportunity to influence the world, to work on projects that save lives, and be a part of something bigger. Much bigger.

And in our lives, we’re only given so many opportunities to do things like that ... most never even get the chance.

Overall, this year has taught me so much about resilience. All of the failures, successes, hopes, dreams, and disappointments that I have experienced have turned into important life lessons. I’ve learned about the importance of giving and of radical generosity. I’ve learned about integrity, respect, and kindness. I’ve tried to be generous with my time and I’ve tried to be of service to others. And as I look forward to the next few years, I can only hope that all these lessons I’ve learned can be used to help spur the potential of tens of millions more people around the world.

We have a lot of work ahead and we need to raise a lot of money to make it happen, but I feel grateful for 2020. I’ve been given the opportunity of a lifetime and I’m running with it. I might be wrong, but I think the FinMango story has just begun… Let’s jump on the train!

Stay tuned and learn how to support our work at finmango.org.

title: COVID-19 Policy Brief
excerpt: By OJ SINGHDuring the COVID-19 pandemic, the Effective Reproduction Number – Re – has been the go-to metric for most government agencies and public health officials.
body:
By OJ SINGH

During the COVID-19 pandemic, the Effective Reproduction Number – Re – has been the go-to metric for most government agencies and public health officials.

Re is a metric used to gauge the transmissibility of a disease; by calculating Re, governments can implement various intervention strategies, applying them at the degree required, to mitigate the spread of that disease.

Re is determined by three factors: how infectious the infected person is, how many susceptible people the average infector meets in a day, and how many days the infector remains infectious.

The incubation period for the virus is between 5-6 days, however, the recommended range is 1-14 days; this is why many protocols require quarantining for 14 days after coming in contact with an infected person. The average infection period for COVID-19 is 12 days, often starting a few days after symptoms appear.

So, what Re should policymakers aim for in order to effectively manage the pandemic?

When Re is greater than 1, that means that each infected person infects more than one other person; the virus grows exponentially, and Re increases. When Re is less than 1, that means that not every infected person infects someone else.

The goal is to keep Re below 1 – this doesn’t signal a rapid decline in new cases, it signals that with a constant Re below 1, the number of cases per day will slowly decline to 0 over a period of time, as fewer and fewer people are infected.

As mitigation strategies are implemented and uplifted, and individuals interact within unprecedented environments, Re is constantly changing. Government agencies and public health officials should use their area’s Re to create plans appropriate for their specific circumstances and objectives.

Hugh Murrell and Daniel Murrell, two researchers from South Africa, relied on FinMango’s South Africa COVID-19 data to create a simple algorithm to calculate Re, so those without in-depth statistical knowledge can understand data and trends in layman’s terms. They uploaded their technique on GitHub, so that anyone can personalize models and tweak parameters for their specific circumstances. To conduct the industrial-scale algorithms at a fast pace, the researchers switched from using the University of Pretoria’s data to using FinMango’s data, as FinMango was accurately publishing granular data in a timely fashion from previously unreported districts.

Using this Re model, policymakers should implement lockdowns, face covering policies, social distancing regulations, curfews, contact tracing, widespread testing, and whatever else is necessary to contain COVID-19.

Some governments, like those of Vietnam and New Zealand, will choose to go into full lockdown and shut down all non-essential activity, conduct extensive contact tracing and widespread testing, and implement travel restrictions to contain the virus and keep it contained.

Other governments, like those of France and Spain, will initially shut down to flatten the curve, and then open back up, after assembling what they believe is necessary medical infrastructure and testing protocols. Recently, both Spain and France have gone back into lockdown. Spain imposed a national curfew to combat its second wave of the virus three days ago. France declared a second national lockdown, as cases soared, this morning.

Whatever policymakers do, ethically, their goal must be to save as many lives as possible.

‍
